dublin_core.dcvalue: The effect of three types of cell phones hand held hands free with an external speaker and personal hands free on total subjective workload including its constituent components mental demand physical demand temporal demand performance effort and frustration and intelligibility was measured using the NASA task load index TLX and the modified rhyme test MRT respectively in 13 experienced drivers nine male four female age range 28 65 years whilst driving on a rural highway The drivers rated all components of workload for each type of cell phone to be significantly higher than for a control condition in which no cell phone was used The mean standard deviation total workload was lowest for the personal hands free cell phone 7 1 3 65 and highest for the hands free speaker phone 10 8 3 63 PUnder0 001 The mean standard deviation intelligibility score was highest for the personal hands free cell phone 74 1 7 9 and lowest for the hands free speaker phone 55 0 10 4 PUnder0 001 Frustration was significantly correlated with total workload 0 60 PUnder0 001 and intelligibility was significantly correlated with frustration 0 35 PUnder0 05 Physical demand was not a high contributor to total workload It is concluded that a personal hands free cell phone would interfere least with the cognitive demands of driving
Made available in DSpace on 2020-02-06T16:07:36Z (GMT). No. of bitstreams: 0 Previous issue date: 2003-05-05
The effect of cell phone type on drivers subjective workload during concurrent driving and conversing.
